page.title: 15The Beacon.
page.content: {The Beacon}is so named because it was here that a fire was lit to convey the alarm when{the Spaniards}attempted invasion in{1588.}From the top there is a magnificent view of the surrounding scenery.To the{east} {Barnstaple}, on the nearside{Heanton} {hill.}Due south is the confluence of {the Taw and the Torridge}forming the estuary which leads out to{the Bar. {Appledore}is visible across the estuary,and on it's near bank{Braunton {Pill}reaches into{Velator.}Away to the west is{Saunton}with it's sandhills,to the south{Hartland Point and the {island of Lundy}a dozen miles out into the{Bristol Channel.}This is the spot to also see the vast pattern of the Great field and to see how large the environs of Braunton have now become.
